thread.title: Gazprom, European partners sign Nord Stream-2 deal
thread.title_full: Gazprom, European partners sign Nord Stream-2 deal

title: Gazprom, European partners sign Nord Stream-2 deal
text:
* Project to double existing Baltic pipeline's capacity 
* All companies mentioned as interested are on board 
* Russia provides for about a third of EU energy needs (Adds context, detail) 
FRANKFURT/VLADIVOSTOK, Russia, Sept 4 (Reuters) - Russia's Gazprom and its European partners signed a shareholders' agreement on the Nord Stream-2 gas pipeline project that will run beneath the Baltic Sea to Europe, bringing Europe closer into Moscow's energy orbit. 
Russia provides for around a third of EU energy needs, but around half of the gas the EU imports from Gazprom is shipped via Ukraine, with which Russia is in conflict. It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) wants to find new ways to deliver gas to Europe bypassing its neighbour. 
Gazprom, E.ON, BASF/Wintershall , OMV (Amsterdam: OM6.AS - news ) , ENGIE (Other OTC: ENGIY - news ) and Royal Dutch Shell (LSE: RDSB.L - news ) formed the new consortium for the project, a spokesman for the consortium said on Friday. 
Gazprom is fighting to defend market share in Europe in the face of oversupplied gas markets, betting on rising long-term demand as Europe's indigenous gas sources are declining. 
Led by Gazprom, which has put the cost of the plan at up to 9.9 billion euros ($11 billion) and maybe less due to savings, the group is to build a third and fourth pipeline to transport up to 55 billion additional cubic meters of gas a year. 
It would double the capacity of lines 1 and 2, which take the same route. The new pipelines are due to start transporting gas by the end of 2019. ($1 = 0.8985 euros) (Reporting by Katya Golubkova and Vera Eckert in Frankfurt,; Editing by Tom Hogue and Georgina Prodhan)
